repository.corpname: Ohio State University Libraries Special Collections

did.abstract: Hugh Nissenson was an American author whose fiction dealt extensively with American life, depression, and Judaism. The Hugh Nissenson Papers date from the 1940s to 2013, and contain drafts and manuscripts of published and unpublished materials, an extensive autobiographical journal detailing his writing process, and other papers relating to Nissenson's personal and professional life.
did.physdesc: (56) 5" letter document boxes; (2) 5" legal boxes; (1) 2.5" legal documet box; (1) flat box; (4) costume boxes; (3) oversize document boxes; (1) oversize folder

arrangement.head: Arrangement of Materials
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in 4 series: Series 1: Professional Papers Series 2: Published Works Series 3: Personal Papers Series 4: Unpublished Works

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [identification of item], Hugh Nissenson Papers, SPEC.RARE.0138, Rare Books and Manuscripts Library, Ohio State University

accessrestrict.head: Access to Materials
accessrestrict.p: Materials in this collection are available for patron research, but may be used in the Thompson Library Special Collections reading room only.

userestrict.head: Use of Materials
userestrict.p: Materials in this collection may be protected by copyright, and are made available for research and educational purposes. In general, the OSU Libraries do not own the copyright for materials from our collections and cannot grant copyright permissions for these materials. The user is responsible for making a final determination of copyright status. If copyright protection applies, permission must be obtained from the copyright holder to reuse, publish, or reproduce the work beyond the bounds of fair use or other exceptions to the law. Works in the public domain are not protected by copyright and do not require permission to use.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by: John Dewees, 2014 December; Finding aid written by: John Dewees, 2014 December; Courtney Bishop, 2017 October

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Hugh Nissenson (1933-2013) was an American author. Nissenson was born in New York City and lived there his whole life. He was educated at the Fieldstone School in the Bronx and received an undergraduate degree from Swarthmore College in 1955. Nissenson's published works include non-fiction and autobiographical work, but he was most well-known for his fiction, including his short-stories and novels. Nissenson published one memoir, three collections of short stories and five novels, in addition to numerous short stories published in serials and periodicals. Nissenson's work dealt with issues of life in America and also touched extensively on Judaism, a topic explored in his first novel "My Own Ground." While critically well received, his works were never commercially successful, an issue which contributed to his ongoing depression.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Hugh Nissenson Papers contain materials dated between the 1940s and 2013. Included in the collection are drafts and manuscripts of published and unpublished materials, an extensive autobiographical journal detailing his writing process, and other papers relating to Nissenson's personal and professional life. These materials primarily take the form of loose-leaf, letter size paper, or bound volumes such as datebooks or journals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Professional Papers series contains papers directly related to Nissenon's career as a professional writer without being one of his creative works. This includes awards, interviews, speeches he gave, reviews of other writer's work, and commentary about his own work by other writers. This series spans the 1960s to the 2000s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains two awards bestowed upon Nissenson for his works "A Pile of Stones" (awarded in 1966) and "The Song of the Earth" (awarded in 2002). These awards take the form of paper documents.

did.unittitle: Edward Lewis Wallant Memorial Book Award

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains publisher-requested biographies for inclusion in press and marketing materials. These biographical documents were written by Nissenson himself.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains two interviews with Nissenson, the undated Vialione interview being done for an Italian publication. The Klin interview took place in 2003.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains copies of articles written about Nissenson's work by other individuals not in the form of a review, generally by academics. These range in date from 1979 to the 2000s, with one document undated.

did.unittitle: History and Myth in the Novel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains reviews Nissenson did of other published materials, in 1969 and another written at an unknown time.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains speeches that Nissenson gave in his capacity as a professional writer. These spanned his life from the 1970s to the 2000s and in many cases were undated, and even untitled, providing little context to the circumstances when they were given.

did.unittitle: Literary Creativity and the Publishing Industry

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Published Works series contains materials present in looseleaf, letter sized paper, generally not bound in any way. Papers present either represent non-fiction, such as his reporting on the war crimes trials of Eichmann and Barbie, and also his autobiographical work, or American fiction, as in the case of all his short stories and novels. Materials were produced from 1960 to 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Personal Papers series contains materials not directly related to Nissenon's professional writing, including his personal journal entries, papers related to his family, and correspondence. Of particular note is the "journal" sub-series which provides an excellent narrative of Nissenson's life from his own perspective. This series spans Nissenon's entire life from the 1940s to the 2010s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains all of Nissenson's written correspondence from the 1960s to the 2010s. In the 2000s and 2010s this includes emails, which were printed out. All correspondence with Cynthia Ozick was set aside in Box 21, folder 4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With the exception of the 1976 calendar, this sub-series contains all of Nissenson's datebooks from 1985 to 2012, all produced by the Paris Ritz-Carlton. It appears that Nissenson tended to use them sporadically throughout his life, but almost never missed having one for a year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains two primary sets of materials: drawings done by his daughters in the 1970s and items from his daughter Kate's wedding in 2008.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains bound journals that Nissenson used to jot down thoughts, sketch, write down appointments and phone numbers, and generally get his thoughts onto paper. Nissenson used these extensively through his life from the 1960s to the 2010s. These stand in contrast to the sub-series "journal" which provides a narrative and autobiographical description of Nissenson's life (see associated scope/contents note).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Unpublished Works series contains all creative materials produced by Nissenson that were not able to be verified as published, and thus presumed unpublished. The first portion of this series contains written works, primarily short stories, many of which are undated and untitled. The second portion of this series contains visual artwork that Nissenson produced, primarily for his own enjoyment and not for the intention of publically showing. This series spans Nissenson's life from his early life as a writer, attempting to get short stories published to his later life when he was more frequently sketching and producing visual art.
